talk.start.para: On the lst March the honorable member for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr. J. R. Eraser) asked the following question: â

quote.para: I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government has under consideration a proposal to amend the Seat of Government (Administration) Act so as to incorporate in that enactment the provisions of section 02 of the Constitution, as has been done in a comparable act relating to thc Northern Territory. As this matter bears so directly on the transport of goods by road from thc Slate of New South Wales to tho Australian Capital Territory, and thus is reflected in the cost of materials and the prices of commodities here, will the Prime Minister take the earliest opportunity to make some announcement on the matter?

question.para: As I promised the honorable member I have discussed this matter with my colleague, the Attorney-General. The question of applying the provisions of section 92 of the Constitution to the Australian Capital Territory is not a new concept and has been under consideration on previous occasions. It has been rejected in the past because the making of such a provision, while it would confer upon the Territory the benefit of section 92, would also import into the laws of the Territory the difficulties of the section. As the honorable member is no doubt aware these difficulties are serious and probably have not yet been completely solved either in a constitutional or a legal sense. Consequently the Government does not intend to take the course recommended by the honorable member, but the question would appear to be a proper one for reference to the proposed committee on the Constitution.

talk.start.para: On the 28th February, the honorable member for Shortland(Mr. Griffiths), asked the following question:â

quote.para: In view of the large number of employees being dismissed from the coal-mining industry, I ask the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's project at Lucas Heights, and also at the ammunition filling factory at St. Mary's, oil furnaces are to be installed instead of coal-burning boilers. Is it a fact that in Britain similar projects are being equipped with coal-burning boilers, so that the coal industry may be protected and developed? If these are facts, does the Prime Minister agree that the British authorities, in taking steps to preserve the British coal industry, have shown greater vision than have the Australian authorities? Is it not true that ample stocks of good steaming coal are available at the new State mine at Oakdale for use at both plants? In view of the national importance attached to the preservation of the Australian coal industry, will the Prime Minister have inquiries made to ascertain whether it is desirable and economically sound, to have, oil used instead of coal at the projects now in question, and will he associate with his inquiry an investigation into whether coal or oil is being used in England in similar projects as well as what other action the British Government is taking to preserve its coal industry?

question.para: My colleagues, the Ministers for Defence Production, National Development and Supply have now advised me that the question appears to be predicated on the erroneous belief that the problems of the British coal industry are similar to those of the Australian coal industry. The essential problem of the British industry is under-production in relation to demand. This is not now a problem for the Australian industry. I wish to make it plain that the problems of the Australian industry and notably of the industry in New South Wales with which the Commonwealth has a particular concern have in my view been attacked with commendable vigour and imagination.The Commonwealth Government is in daily touch with the situation of the coal industry in Australia. It is deeply concerned about the position of displaced workers in the industry and is doing all it can to find additional markets for the industry's surplus coal. In cases where men have lost their employment at particular mines, all possible assistance is being given to finding employment for these men elsewhere. At the same time it is possible that the extent of the difficulties facing the industry may be exaggerated. The latest figures available show the following numbers of men registered for employment in the industry as at the 7th April:âSout h coast, nil; Cessnock district, 330; Newcastle district, 75; western district, 14.

It will be seen that nearly all the men out of employment are in the Cessnock district.This is due to tbe closure some two months ago of the Bell Bird colliery and the dismissal of 560 men. A series of negotiations has occurred since this mine was closed and it is now ready to be re-opened as soon as a dispute between the management and men is settled. When the mine re-opens employment will be provided within four or five weeks for some 230-250 men. The balance of the men will be absorbed in other mines through normal wastage such as retirements and resignations. Subsequent to the Bell Bird dismissals 203 men were retrenched on the 9th March on the closure of Stockrington No. 1 colliery in the Newcastle district. All except 50 had obtained other employment by the 24th March and these will soon be absorbed in other mines or industries in the Newcastle area. A further 90 dismissals from Killingworth colliery in the Newcastle district have just taken place. It is expected that other mines and industries in the district will absorb these men within a reasonable period. This must be considered a reasonably satisfactory position when it is remembered that some 2,300 mine-workers have been displaced since the 1st January, 1955. The great majority of these men quickly found other employment.

Commonwealth departments and other authorities take great care to explore thoroughly the merits and demerits of using coal or oil in any plant installed by them. In the case of St. Mary's ammunition factory, the decision to use oil burners was taken on the recommendation of engineering consultants after they had made a most careful examination, taking into account all the peculiar needs of this particular factory. The view of these consultants was that it appeared both desirable and economically sound in this case to use oil. However, the plant is being designed so that if the need arises, conversion to coal-firing can be readily achieved.

The Atomic Energy Commission is still examining the type of steam-raising plant to be installed at Lucas Heights and has not yet decided whether coal or oil will be used. In the course of its inquiries on the subject it is obtaining confirmation as to the type of steam-raising plant being used in the latest atomic energy installations in the United Kingdom.

There are no stocks of coal at the State mine at Oakdale which will not come into production until the end of May, 1956. There will be no demand for steam-raising either at St. Mary's or at Lucas Heights, either at that date or for some time thereafter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Are hormone-salicylate combinations, using prednisone and prednisolone, available in Australia, and what is the cost of the tablets ?
Are these drugs effective in the treatment of arthritic and rheumatic diseases?
Are the tablets available under (a) the general national health scheme, and (b) the pensioner medical scheme ?
If not, will consideration be given to making them so available?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: From inquiries made, it would appear that no stocks of these substances are held in Australia.
Some American publications report that hormone salicylate compounds are effective in the treatment of arthritic and rheumatic diseases. However, no clinical evidence has as yet reached my department.
No. See 1.
All applications for the listing of drugs as benefits are referred to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee for consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

item.para: Is it the intention of the Government to retain occupancy of lands taken over by it during the war years?
Does much of the land in question comprise former park lands and playgrounds?
Is continued occupancy of these areas causing considerable inconvenience and hardship to municipal authorities such as the Municipality of Leichhardt, New South Wales?
Can he indicate when these lands will be restored to their original authorities?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: No. Wherever possible action to vacate is taken.
Yes, but in all cases with the possible exception of King George Park, New South Wales, leases have been arranged.

Generally, local authorities have agreed to grant leases. In the case of Leichhardt Park, 6 acres of the total area of 32 acres is held under lease from the council for ten years from the 1st October, 1950.
Every effort is being made to vacate those areas where the local authority requires possession.
